turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Big Sky (song).
turn.1: What kind of change did the song Big Sky bring to the Buffalo Springfield?
turn.2: The song was performed in a more heavy rock style, which Andy Miller described as "horrible.
turn.3: Did the song stay with the band?
turn.4: " The song was dropped from the band's live set after 1972, and has been performed by Ray Davies live on occasion in the 21st century.
turn.5: What other interesting information can you tell me about the song?
turn.6: "Big Sky" first saw release on " The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society", where it was the sixth track.
turn.8: Despite not being released as a single, the song also appeared on the compilation album "Picture Book" and the bootleg album "Good Luck Charm".
turn.10: Critic Robert Christgau noted the track for being "an acrimonious anti-religious song which exemplifies fictional song technique." "Rolling Stone" praised "the almost mystical resignation of 'Big Sky,' which transplants 'Waterloo Sunset' to an equally unforgiving country locale." Author Andy Miller greatly commended the track, saying "the Kinks' version of 'Big Sky' contains some of the most beautiful, thunderous music they ever recorded, aligned to a vulnerability and warmth no other group - and I mean no other group - could ever hope to equal.
turn.11: What did other critics say about it?
turn.12: It is a perfectly balanced production." Ray Davies himself has claimed that "Big Sky" was one of his favorite Kinks songs, despite being unhappy with the Kinks' performance of the track.
